articles.headline: Fed Cuts Rate but Hints About a Pause
articles.snippet: Following new indications that the economy remained fragile at best, the Federal Reserve cut key short-term rates another quarter point.
articles.abstract: Following new indications that the economy remained fragile at best, the Federal Reserve cut key short-term rates another quarter point.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, mixing concern about the feeble economy with worries about rising inflation, reduced short-term interest rates Wednesday for the seventh time since September, while signaling a pause in any additional rate cuts for now.

articles.headline: For Europe’s Middle-Class, Stagnant Wages Stunt Lifestyle
articles.snippet: Families that once enjoyed Europe’s vaunted quality of life are pinching pennies to buy necessities, and cutting back on extras like movies and vacations abroad.
articles.abstract: Families that once enjoyed Europe’s vaunted quality of life are pinching pennies to buy necessities, and cutting back on extras like movies and vacations abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: LES ULIS, France  When their local bakery in this town south of Paris raised the price of a baguette for the third time in six months, Anne-Laure Renard and Guy Talpot bought a bread maker. When gasoline became their biggest single expense, they sold one of their two cars.
articles.byline: By Carter Dougherty and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Prominent Green Group to Help Buyout Firm
articles.snippet: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm, plans to announce a new partnership with the Environmental Defense Fund.
articles.abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm, plans to announce a new partnership with the Environmental Defense Fund.
articles.byline: By Felicity Barringer and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Afghans See Link to Qaeda in Plot to Shoot Karzai
articles.snippet: The Afghan intelligence chief said the attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai was the work of militants who had infiltrated his country’s security forces.
articles.abstract: The Afghan intelligence chief said the attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai was the work of militants who had infiltrated his country’s security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai on Sunday was the work of militants who had infiltrated Afghanistan’s security forces and had ties to groups linked to Al Qaeda in Pakistan’s tribal areas, the Afghan intelligence chief said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Abdul Waheed Wafa

articles.headline: Fewer Latino Immigrants Sending Money Home
articles.snippet: More than three million Latin American immigrants in the U.S. have stopped sending remittances, a survey said.
articles.abstract: More than three million Latin American immigrants in the U.S. have stopped sending remittances, a survey said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign that the economic downturn is hitting hard among Latino immigrants, more than three million of them stopped sending money to families in their home countries during the last two years, the Inter-American Development Bank said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: A Strained Wright-Obama Bond Finally Snaps
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama’s falling out with his former pastor was long and painful, say friends and aides.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama’s falling out with his former pastor was long and painful, say friends and aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late Monday night, in the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C., Barack Obama’s long, slow fuse burned to an end. Earlier that day he had thumbed through his BlackBerry, reading accounts of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.’s latest explosive comments on race and America. But his remarks to the press this day had amounted to a shrug of frustration.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: China Says Abusive Child Labor Ring Is Exposed
articles.snippet: Authorities said they had “rescued” more than 100 children from factories in a manufacturing center.
articles.abstract: Authorities said they had “rescued” more than 100 children from factories in a manufacturing center.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China said Wednesday that it had broken up a child labor ring that forced children from poor, inland areas to work in booming coastal cities, acknowledging that severe labor abuses extended into the heart of its export economy.

articles.headline: TV Images to Dazzle the Jaded
articles.snippet: What has an 11-inch screen, offers breathtaking pictures and costs $2,500? It’s the new TV from Sony.
articles.abstract: What has an 11-inch screen, offers breathtaking pictures and costs $2,500? It’s the new TV from Sony.
articles.lead_paragraph: Modern tech life teems with longstanding quandaries, questions that never seem to go away. Mac or Windows? Turn off the computer every night or let it sleep? Plasma or L.C.D.?

articles.headline: Time Warner Refocusing With Move to Spin Off Cable
articles.snippet: The move spotlighted the company’s future as a pure content provider and signaled a renewed focus on its Warner Brothers movie studios and Turner Networks.
articles.abstract: The move spotlighted the company’s future as a pure content provider and signaled a renewed focus on its Warner Brothers movie studios and Turner Networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another era at Time Warner, before a star-crossed Internet merger, the hard-held belief of Gerald M. Levin, then the chief executive, was that “content is and will remain king, but distribution is the power behind the throne.”

articles.headline: Low Spending Is Taking Toll on Economy
articles.snippet: Beleaguered American consumers appear to have succumbed to the pressures of falling home prices and shrinking paychecks.
articles.abstract: Beleaguered American consumers appear to have succumbed to the pressures of falling home prices and shrinking paychecks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, beleaguered American consumers have defied expert forecasts that they would soon succumb to the pressures of falling home prices, fewer jobs and shrinking paychecks. Now, they appear to have given in.
